Hi Ken- 

This is a minor quibble on a side comment of yours, but I think i=
t is fun to
think about. I used to be amazed as well that evolution never d=
iscovered the
wheel. But then I realized that wheels are only good with pav=
ement. Since
environments did not have pavement, it is no surprise that evo=
lution did not
discover the wheel. Only a complex process of niche construc=
tion, like we
have done with our road system, allows the chicken/egg proble=
m to be
overcome such that it is worth it to both lay roads and use wheels.=


In natural uneven landscapes, legged creatures are much better than wheel=
ed
creatures. Which is why we can't drive through forests.

So I don't see =
this as a failure of evolution. In fact, we can make good
wheeled creatures=
 but are just barely starting to be able to make good
legged creatures (e.g=
. Big dog). The legged creatures are better and harder
to make than the whe=
el.

What do you think?

That point aside, evolution did discover the wheel=
 in some cases. Such as
dung beetles:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DI1R=
HmSm36aE

Some people also have claimed that evolution has created the whee=
l at the
nano-scale. But I can't remember what the examples were.

None of =
this detracts from your main point, however, which I agree with.

Cheers,
J=
eff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...=





> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yah=
oogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Tue, 05 Aug 2008 10:32:42 -000=
0
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re:=
 Benchmarks for Artificial Embryogeny Systems
> 
> Derek, I also don't beli=
eve there has been a great deal of benchmark
> comparison sine the 2003 pap=
er, although Alexandre Devert cites a
> few.  However, usually when people =
attempt benchmarks they do not
> compare their results explicitly with othe=
rs.
> 
> At the same time, as you know, I have changed my philosophy somewh=
at
> since 2003 because I have realized that benchmark comparisons can
> le=
ad to misunderstanding unless they are controlled very carefully.
> One of =
the problems is the "target-based evolution problem," which
> is one of the=
 inspirations for novelty search.  In short, evolving
> to an arbitrary tar=
get can lead to misleading intuitions about what
> is possible with a parti=
cular encoding because of deception.  Often
> a "failed" encoding very well=
 could represent the target if only it
> had been led to it through an alte=
rnative path through the search
> space.
> 
> Also, another problem with be=
nchmarks is that they may obfuscate
> more fundamental advantages of partic=
ular approaches because they do
> not focus on general capabilities.  (Alth=
ough, of course, if you do
> enough of them, perhaps general capabilities s=
tart to be clearer.)
> But that is why I advocated more focus on looking fo=
r biological-
> like regularities in the patterns output by particular enco=
dings,
> rather than looking for a single particular pattern, or even a
> s=
ingle set of patterns.  Like I've said before, evolution never
> produced a=
 wheel but that hardly means DNA is a bad encoding.
> 
> Of course benchmar=
ks can play a role and I do think more comparisons
> could be done, but we =
also have to be cautious about their
> misapplication.
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> 
> =
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "David D'Ambrosio" <ddambro84@...>
> wrote:
>>=
 
>> Hi Derek,
>> 
>> I'm not really aware of much, if any benchmarking wor=
k that has
> been
>> done in the field other than some of the papers mentio=
ned in the
> other
>> post.  An outsider might think our ultimate goal is t=
o create a
> French
>> flag!  I think it would be great to see such benchma=
rking of
>> artificial embryogeny, as things seem to be about the same as w=
hen
> Ken
>> wrote his paper: everyone is just trying stuff with their own
=
> system,
>> without any regard to the other systems out there.
>> 
>> Ken =
and I did try to do something like (although not as indepth as
> his
>> pap=
er suggests) with my 2007 HyperNEAT paper's results.  I built a
>> program =
that let me look at the Hypercube patterns and we were
> able to
>> learn a=
 lot about HyperNEAT by watching how the patterns changed
> over
>> evoluti=
on, and were able to isolate modules that contributed to
> things
>> like s=
ymmetry.  We have a forthcoming journal publication about
>> HyperNEAT in g=
eneral that talks a bit about this.
>> 
>> David
>> 
>> --- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, "Derek James" <djames@> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Seeing Peter Krcah's stuf=
f (http://ero.matfyz.cz/) at GECCO this
> year
>>> got me re-interested in =
artificial embryogeny. I went back and
> reread
>>> Ken's paper "A Taxonomy=
 for Artificial Embryogeny"
>>> (http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=
=3D121), which is a
> very nice
>>> paper. I was specifically wondering abo=
ut the suggestions at the
> end
>>> of the paper, regarding benchmarks for =
AE systems, such as:
>>> 
>>> Evolution of:
>>> 
>>> --Pure symmetry (e.g. =
bilateral symmetry)
>>> --Specific shapes (e.g. rings, stars, and trees)
>>=
> --Specific connectivity patterns (e.g. for neural networks)
>>> --Simple =
controllers (e.g. for double pole balancing)
>>> 
>>> Ken goes on to say:
>=
>> 
>>> "Such benchmark comparisons will eventually make it possible to
>>>=
 predict the performance
>>> of AE systems based on their location in the t=
axonomy. For
> example, one
>>> benchmark might be to evolve a five-pointed=
 star. This benchmark
> can
>>> be attempted
>>> with a system in which all=
 the dimensions of development are
> fixed
>>> except the cell
>>> fate dim=
ension. That dimension can vary from using only
> prepatterning
>>> to usin=
g every
>>> conceivable form of fate determination, from stochastic
>>> sel=
f-organization to signaling,
>>> migration, and proliferation. The results =
can be measured using
>>> several criteria: How
>>> fast does the objective=
 shape evolve? How often and how many
> genes
>> are reused by
>>> the solu=
tion genome? Is symmetry used, or is each point in the
> star
>>> specified=
 by a separate
>>> section of genetic code=97that is, is there emergent mod=
ularity?
> For
>>> every possible
>>> setting on the varying dimension (e.g=
., cell fate
> determination), data
>>> will be available
>>> for compariso=
n."
>>> 
>>> This sounds like a great idea. I'm wondering, though...what ki=
nd
> of
>>> response has this generated? Have there been any follow up
> pa=
pers on
>>> AE systems that have tried to apply such benchmarks in a
> syst=
ematic
>>> way?
>>> 
>>> Have these types of benchmarks been systematically=
 applied to
> the 2D
>>> representations evolved using HyperNEAT?
>>> 
>>> =
I also noticed rereading Sims 1994 paper that he displays hand-
> coded
>>>=
 examples of recognizable morphologies such as a primate hand, a
>>> humano=
id form, and a tree structure. But I'm wondering if and/or
> how
>>> easy s=
uch structures arise using his encoding when starting from
> a
>>> simple c=
ore structure and either using artificial selection or a
>>> fitness functi=
on tailored to evoke similar structures.
>>> 
>>> --Derek
>>> 
>> 
> 
>
